162538015.review:
Most people don't play No Man's Sky. Not because the concept is bad. Not because the interest isn't there.
... but because the game has an extremely tedious and rough start.

I have always wanted to spend many-many hours in this game, but I've been one of those people that just couldn't get into it, because I had to get over the hill; the beginning of the game. It's an overwhelming process. 

"What does that do? How do I get this? What is this? Can I sell it? Should I? Should I keep it? How do I fly? Can I change controls? This is janky. I'm getting tired of all this information. Oh wait, there's something over there. Let me go check..." *Dies*
"Sigh. Maybe I should try that new game I've thought about purchasing... but I want to play this game, but I should probably take a break."
^ This is the general experience of a beginner. At least from my experience and the people I've influenced to play it, aswell. They always seem very interested before booting up the game, but after 30-60 minutes, their conclusion always ends the same. "So tired, should probably take a break."

BUT... I promise you, review-reader, if you stick with it. Get over that hill. You'll find the best time consuming game money can buy, if you're into space travel, survival, basebuilding, hoarding loot, singleplayer/multiplayer, etc. --- it's got it all.

You're basicly playing a singleplayer game with online multiplayer features, when you're ready for that. Do what you want!

I'm giving this game 10/10. All the constant updates are a reminder that these devs have PASSION for their game... and that folks is all it takes to make a game great. Fantastic game!

Can't wait for the next update and also their next game!

160706123.review:
Broad, but shallow.

The game offers a broad variety of things to do:

-Exploring planets/space stations/star systems
-space fights
-first person gun fights
-trading
-basebuilding
-crafting
-mining
-story
-improving personal gear/ships

The downside is, that most of this feels shallow, or executed in bad ways:

Landing on a planet really feels like landing on an actual planet. Each one is massive, everything on the surface can be visited, there are many buildings/caves/waterbodies/ore patches/treasures/npcs....
Exploring comes down to finding very similiar planets over and over again made out of perhaps 10 different possible biomes. Only little things may vary. Additionally the things to find on each planet are also quite the same. Very soon, it becomes boring to search for and open some treasure chest, just to find some stuff, that can easily be bought elsewhere or crafted. There is no special loot to find, with the exception to a few certain ships.
Everything that can be equipped/piloted can do roughly the same things/has too similar stats, even though there are four grades of ships/equipment.
Which one of which rarity the player uses, doesn't really make that much of a difference gameplay-wise.
The biggest change is often only the way they look.
Most star systems also feel the same: 1 space station, 4 or so planets.
Once docked, space stations themself have little to offer: Roughly the same layout, very small, standard stuff to buy, same npcs...
There are very big ships, warping in in space in a cool looking way, but after that they will just hang around without any movement.

Space fights are kind of semi automatic. Your ship will always fly automatically, you can't stay standing still and stuff like that, even after getting some free-flight equipment/changing the setup.
Additionaly you can have a big fleet, but that's only for some point and klick missions.
Just hanging in space like the other ships, they cannot really fight or fly.
Since equipment/grade doesn't really make that big of a difference, aside from inventoy space, there is not much reason to find and buy better things.

There are many ways to trade: Facilities on planets/stations and npcs.
There might be some ways to make money by buying, then selling at a different place, for a higher price, but it feels like the stock at each trading opportunity is way to low to allow for big profit. I got the impression that profits are way higher by just selling some mined, planted or crafted things, or doing certain missions.
I found no exotic, trade exclusive goods to explore/search for on trade terminals. Everything is just stuff, that was offered so many different times before.

The main story/ies seemed to be kind of interesting, but that was not enough to make me continue the game.

Base building seems to offer many different parts with different forms, colors and patterns.
To me, it seemed like here lay one main point of focus of the developers.
Where cosmetic aspects are concerned, this seems to allow for many, very diverse base designs.
Such structures can also employ some gameplay tasks.
For example they can be teleported to and from, allowing for fast travel even across many star systems.
Additionaly automated mining and cultivating of important crops can be done within the operation limit of bases.
Those materials could then be sold, or refined into different resources, leading to many different recipes for crafting/refining.
Since refiners cannot be automated, and have very limited inventory space, the player would always need to come back personally, in order to input new materials and take out the refined products. 
No production chains are possible, no autocrafting, no automated bringing of materials from and to storage.

This leads to some of the MOST ANNOYING aspects of the game: HORRIBLE UI design choices 

-New materials to use for refining have to be taken from a little inventory screen that can NOT be sorted, NOT be filtered, NOT be searched for specific things. One would HAVE to always scroll though that little inventory. ''Surprisingly'' this will become very annoying, very fast. 
The more materials you hold, the bigger the annoyance.
-The number of items to craft/trade would have to be manually increased one by one.
-Ships/multitools you do own, cannot be sold, if they are not your current selected one.
-You cannot see the details of the ship/tool you are selling, so the wrong one may be sold.
-Switching out and moving around modules of a ship/multitool seems to be needlessly complicated.
-Many ever-present tasks can only be done by browsing sub-menus, such as accepting communication signals, ...

I do not understand why those things have not been fixed for more than seven years, or why they where even done like that to begin with!
I am sure this could have been done better, even for a gaming console focused game!

So at the end, to me, No Man's Sky is a game that tries to offer many things, but fails to give most of them sufficient depth, paired with some reaaaaally annoying design choices and bugs.

158053400.review:
Obviously Hello Games deserves credit for the work they've put into this game since its disastrous launch. Unfortunately, the core gameplay loop has not changed and remains highly repetitive and tedious. 

Almost every single objective is to  go from point A to point B, perform some action, then return. This would be fine if the journey actually involved some challenge or intrigue, but for normal game modes, this is mind-numbingly dull. All obstacles, either planet side or in space can be trivially overcome. Ship out of fuel? Blast some comets that always spawns 20 metres away. Life support low? Oh how convenient there's the same oxygen rich planet that grows on Every. Single. One. of the 18 quintillion planets.

What's worse is that content updates have now become focused on "expeditions", which is basically the process described above but for TIME LIMITED rewards. That's right. You better grind away otherwise you're never seeing that content again. Sure there is multiplayer but any kind of meaningful interaction rarely occurs because everyone is trying to walk/fly/swim to the next marker point slightly faster than everybody else, since that's the only challenge this game poses. 

In conclusion, I believe this game is targeted to a somewhat niche group of people who enjoys very slow paced game play. I applaud Hello Games' effort to improve this game over time. However, for me and many others who are looking for a meaningful space sim and exploration experience, No Man's Sky fits the bill very poorly.

Edit: Admittedly I wrote this review out of frustration because I wanted to get all the portal glyphs so I could visit a really cool base I saw online, but it was taking hours longer than expected. However, it really is impossible to stay mad at this game and once again my hat's off to Hello Games for releasing another amazing update. I still think the core gameplay loop is genuinely flawed but I think I might give this game another go.

159015089.review:
Unfortunately, this game DOES NOT run on average laptops.

Most of my playtime is on other consoles, such as Xbox and Playstation.

I've heard people complain that things feel repetitive, and to be fair, it kind of is, but the thing is, everything is just distinct enough to still give a feeling of wonder. Especially when you find an anomalous planet, there are various types, and even when you come across a variant you've seen before, you still think "huh, neat." and appreciate the rare find.

The thing that mostly sells this game to me though is base building. I played Subnautica much more than I have NMS, and loved the building system, but I always felt restricted with my base building being pretty much restricted to just underwater. NMS scratched that itch by letting me build similar structures AND MORE in all kinds of different environments. Whether it be underwater research bases like I made in Subnautica, a sci-fi village on a desert world like that one from Star Wars, and even building space cities with the FUCKING AWESOME freighter building system. You want to build a custom cyber city? With a little practice and a freighter, just enter creative mode and watch your dreams come true! I sometimes spend a week hyperfixating on one base, then spend the next week just gawking at it and having self roleplays as I interact with the random NPCs walking around, making up a story. Great times.

The ONLY real complaint I have about this game:

Legacy cosmetics.

Unfortunately, this game DOES use a FOMO (fear of missing out) system with it's events, most of which I missed sadly. Some of them are really cool too, and I hope they bring them back in some way. I just have an awful schedule with the intervals I play the game at. I take a break from it for a few weeks, come back and find out I missed an event or the event ends really really soon. I've just made a deal with myself to just not participate in events to avoid getting envious about it.

Aside from that small tragedy, this game is really fun, has a neat story that's pretty much optional, especially in creative, and I can't see myself permanently putting it down for a long time from now.

And don't worry, for you bloodthirsty players, there is an outlaw faction, and epic space battles not too disimilar to Star Wars. You fly through ship trenches and blow shit up, pull maneuvers on bogeys and obliterate them when you get the upper hand, and watch as the cowards warp away as you go and collect the rather valuable drops from broken ships.

I personally don't have much experience with the outlaw faction, but sometimes I will make a save just for the purpose of being a lone pirate, cracking freighters open, assaulting random ships, there's something for everyone.

9/10 game, been around since the start. I'm happy to have seen it grow.

159067988.review:
I have been wanting to play No Man's Sky since its initial release and I have to say, I am impressed with how far the game has come after all the updates. When it was first released, the game received a lot of backlash for not living up to its promises and for being repetitive and lacking in content. However, with the release of multiple updates, the game has transformed into a much more immersive and enjoyable experience.

One of the biggest improvements is the addition of a story mode. In the past, the game felt aimless as players were just exploring random planets without any real purpose. But now, with the addition of a story, there is a sense of direction and purpose to the gameplay. The story itself is interesting and keeps me engaged, making me want to continue playing to see how it unfolds.

Another major update that I appreciate is the improved graphics and visuals. The environments and the creatures now look more diverse and realistic. The addition of new biomes and weather effects also adds to the immersive experience of exploring different planets. It's truly amazing to see such a vast and beautiful universe within the game.

The gameplay mechanics have also been significantly improved. The addition of base building and the ability to own and command a freighter have added more depth to the gameplay. The crafting system has been expanded, allowing players to create a variety of items and upgrades. It's great to see that there are now more things to do besides just exploring.

The community aspect of the game has also been enhanced with the inclusion of multiplayer. It's exciting to team up with friends and explore the universe together, or compete against each other in races and battles. Multiplayer definitely adds a whole new dimension to the game and makes it more enjoyable.

Of course, there are still some areas that could use improvement, such as the variety of missions and NPCs. But overall, I am very happy with the updates and improvements that have been made to No Man's Sky. It has become a much more engaging and fulfilling game, and I find myself spending hours playing without getting bored.

In conclusion, I highly recommend giving No Man's Sky another chance if you were disappointed with its initial release. The updates have transformed it into a truly unique and enjoyable game that offers endless possibilities. I can't wait to see what the future holds for this ever-evolving universe.

161617041.review:
Okay, let's be constructive with the review here, since I rarely, if ever, would say "I do not recommend this game" to others. The game received an astounding amount of love from the developer, something that they should be praised for; however, this review is about the product, not how awesome Hello Games is. The studio, in my eyes, deserves a 10/10 rating.

First, the pros of the game:

- Exploration: This is its major strength. There are so many worlds in the whole game, it's amazing, and they all look beautiful.
- Building: You can have a ship, an outpost, your own base, etc., and there is a lot of customization.
- Space simulation: This is another great point. You can not only own a spaceship but also a capital ship and a fleet.
- Numerous races: You get to learn languages to even communicate, and there are some interesting people to meet, at least at first sight.
- Mysterious and ethereal: There is some overarching story which makes one think deeply.

Cons:

- Boring: Simply said, yeah, you can do all the above, but after getting this perfect base, this perfect fleet of ships, and an outpost, you just continue mining for the same resources (or automated so all you do is collect), and then there is just nothing else to do. Sure, a new world will have nice visuals and randomly placed points of interest that you can find on the 99th or 181st planet you see.
- Uninteresting NPCs: Calling them NPCs is actually too much. You can have hires in your spaceship or in your base or outpost... but they really feel like biological interfaces that you can use to get another fetch quest or some service.
- Nothing happens in the universe: No factions that would change diplomacy against each other, all space stations are filled with NPCs that don't really do anything.
- End goal: I will avoid spoilers, but the end goal is pretty uninteresting...
- No female characters: Seriously, WHY? I had numerous friends who refused to play this game with me due to feeling excluded. They can't immerse themselves playing a character with a rough male model.

Summary:

This game is definitely good for people who do not demand more from games in terms of narrative and depth, just sit and tinker a bit. Pretty much people who like to play with Lego would definitely enjoy doing the same things over and over. Its a perfect sandbox sci-fi game and this is both where the strengths and weaknesses are.

If you are, however, a player who wants engaging NPCs, the world reacting to what you do, or even doing things outside of your own influence to try to engage you on its own, then no, this won't be interesting enough for you. It will just become boring with time, and no amount of building/mining or fetch questing will keep you interested. As I am in the latter group of people, hence I cannot with clear conscience recommend this game to others. If this featured some sort of procedural generated NPC's that I could actually communicate with, like my crew going to mess hall in my capital ship to eat or someone searching for me for help or even an NPC I hired with name having some sort of past they would share with me based on some sort of relationship points with them, then it wouldn't leave this hollow feeling I have gotten after 132 hours in the game.

162953771.review:
It pains me to put a "No" here, but after playing this game little by little over the years, I am simply amazed that 8 years later, the GUI is identical to how it started, and equally as bad and frustrating.
The game is fun. It looks great. Cool atmosphere. But playing it through this sluggish slow UI and having to watch the same damaged machinery animation thousands of times when I'm exploring, or having to fumble through the various inventories, or the fact that every NPC tells you their entire life's story every time you just want to buy a wiring loom. The game is supposed to be relaxing, but I am nearing carpel tunnel from mashing left click through dialog and animations.

I would understand if it came out like this, but it has been 8 years, they have remade the game like 3 times, but the UI is unloved.

Heres a detailed list of my struggles with the UI, in a vague hope that a dev will read it:
1) Damaged machinery. I don't know you can get the idea of opening a loot chest wrong, but hold E, grab goo, put it in exosuit, exit the UI, wait 1 second for the interaction button to appear, hold E again, get the loot you actually want. why? just have it give me the goo and loot by holding E once. Same with the green cargo boxes. The yellow and red ones work just fine.
2) Have 2 buttons when you see an NPC. one for "talk" and one for "actions". When I'm checking my inventory and comparing stuff in a shop, since you don't have a side by side view, I have to mash through the same line of dialog from the shop NPC 5 or more times.
3) When repairing something, and I dont have a ready carbon nanotube, which I never will just have laying around, let me hold E on the grayed out carbon nanotube to craft one and use it in one action. Instead of making me exit that UI, go into my exosuit, craft the item, and go back into the UI.
4) Setting actions to "always instant" instead of "hold" applies to only about 50% of the game, and I can never tell if an action is hold or click. 
5) Right click to go back is extremely inconsistent. Sometimes it leaves a UI entirely, other times it goes back to the previous menu. It forces me to repeatedly open the same NPC UI, mashing through the text again, if I want to do multiple actions in that UI. For example unlocking multiple items in the anomaly tech trees.
6) The overly dramatic achievement achievement popups that BLOCK all input until you dismiss it, constantly. This denial of service attack on my gaming experience is THE MOST annoying UI element of this game. Would a notification at the bottom right like all the other notifications not work? Do I have to watch a full screen achievement movie every 10k units I walk?
7) Changing camera view for both player and ship is tucked away in a nested menu instead of being a hotkey
8) The "x" menu is horizontal, while a mouse scroll wheel is vertical. There is no brain association between up/down and left/right.
9) What is up with owning several spaceships? They seem to appear and disappear around me like they are ghosts haunting my game. Why is there no spaceship or multitool menu like the fleet menu? The only way to select a primary ship is to go sit in it. Why are these 2 actions tied? Why do this 1000 IQ system where ships secretly appear in my freighter instead of giving me a menu to manage them?
10) Items in the discoveries menu lists fade into existence at a rate of one per second. I just want to see if I have unuploaded discoveries, not watch a list slowly fade in dramatically. Wrong place to put atmospheric animations.
11) Finally the UI in general is terribly fitted for use with a mouse and keyboard. Compare playing No Man's Sky with any MMORPG from the last 20 years, they all have much better user interfaces for mouse and keyboard without losing immersion or atmosphere for not having fancy animations on every action. I get that maintaining 2 concurrent UI systems is harder than maintaining one, but are you really ok with this?

Honorary non-UI complaints:
1) Lights don't actually light anything up at night time. If you have a building full of lights, only the lights glow, there is no light being cast, everything is still pitch dark.
2) Some sounds in the game are way too loud, like creatures fussing around and freighter hangar shutters opening/closing
3) No option to disable the horrendous scan line effect on the screen that hurts my eyes without modding the game.
4) Different missions will often lead the player to the same building on the same planet repeatedly

Just feels overall like no one play tests this game. Did none of the devs do a run in their own game? Do they all only play on console?

I hope I can change this review to a "Yes" in a future update

161344339.review:
Sean Murray started off in the space game genre like a deadbeat stepdad; all the promises of a new hope, but the same old usual neglect of games flying too close to the sun.

But slowly over the years, something remarkable happened. You see, most space game step daddy's would just come and plant their flag on the space game steam charts, take what the wanted and buggered off. It's what the rest are doing, so why would we expect any better from this one?

But this space daddy, was different.

He stuck around. He contemplated what was wrong with the space game industry. What good he could do if he took his spacebucks invested back into his lost and crying space children. So year after year, that's exactly what he did. 8 years on, and Sean 'Space Daddy' Murray has provided.


He gave us the tools to build a place we could call home together. He gave us new bedtime stories. He let us find new friends in a  big lonely world. He gave us new worlds to see, from freighters to the sea. He gave us living ships, dead ships, pirate ships and mechs. Our quality of life improved, we eventually got companions, moved away from our homes, found new expeditions in life, and new places to call our own. 

Through all the weird and wonderful stuff this crazy old world throws at you, Space Dad didn't give up on us, he knew a foundation to which we built a life amongst the stars, was a good thing worth doing. 

And for 8 years and counting he's never asked us for anything in return. 

To many he might always be a step daddy, but to me, he is my Space Father.

Thank you, Sean. o7

161904853.review:
This game gets held up as a storyline of how to redeem a bad launch by continuing to support it, but those years of content drip have still never made it stop feeling wide as an ocean deep as a puddle. I still play it now and then, but it never leaves me feeling satisfied. I normally don't have strong feelings about this, but this time they've set me off.

This newest update they put out, they finally implemented ship customization, after [b]eight years[/b] of the only way to get a nice looking ship being to hope you randomly get one you like. This is a big glowing headlining feature they're really proud of and have plastered everywhere.
[b]Except it sucks.[/b]
The way you "customize" a ship is to first find or buy ships and salvage them, which lets you make a new ship out of the parts they were made of. That sounds agreeable enough, except that in literally any other game I've ever seen or played that has done something like this, those parts are permanently granted to you in a list you can freely choose from.
Not so here. Each salvaged ship's parts - which you can only pick [b]one[/b] of (wings, cockpit, or engines) [b]per craft[/b] - are physically granted to you in your inventory, which must be brought to the ship terminal and manually used [b]and consumed[/b] to build the new ship, plus a core purchased for nanites to determine its class. It also can only be used on [b]three of the eight[/b] ship types, which excludes all the useful ones. And again, since the parts are all consumed on use, if you got a bad roll on ship stats within that class, well, tough luck. "oh well if they weren't consumed you could rebuild them infinitely until you got optimal stats" They are consumed so they should give optimal stats anyway, give me a break. And if they weren't consumed, they could simply, I don't know... make the process [i]cost money[/i] instead? There's a thought.
It's complete nonsense. I don't understand at all why they would go out of their way to make a worse system than the industry standard and act like they're finally giving the fans what they want. I'd sooner use the long-standing exploits to get one of the custom ships from older expeditions than participate in this absurd time-waster in a game full of time-wasters.

163252666.review: No idea what the game was like in 2016 when it came out, but now that I've finally purchased it and got into it, after listening to a No Man's Sky podcast (The Butcher, the Baker and Candle Maker in Spaaace! from ASA podcasting, where the conversations about the game helped me understand how uniquely versatile it is) I finally decided to give it a go. I'm not at all into online games. Always prefered playing single-player, so I was hesitant to try it. But, the game realy is what you make it, including allowing you to play single-player without any online players and without any limitations. And it seems to be the perfect blend of gameplay and art design for me. Hits the spot absolutely perfectly. It can also get as relaxing and easy-going or as exciting and action-filled as you want it it to be. Endless, seamless exploration, rich and satisfying resource management and base building, and a bit of mystery and unexpected surprises thrown in the mix too. The game oozes creativity and enthusiasm of its authors and from the 30+ hours I put into it, I see why this is one of the greatest redemption stories in gaming. The game plays incredibly well. You can just let it take you into its own universe and you can forget all about the real one. Hats off to the creators. Happy to recommend and support creators who are all about making their game the best possible, not because it brings them profit, but because they care about gaming. Absolutely recommended.

This is a great example of what games should be. The developers put out a really bad game but have diligently been fixing it, adding free content that is better then most paid dlc (and a lot of them 27 as of right now with more on the way) and they have been listening to the community. I can't think of a single better redemption arc then Hello Games; they have gone above and beyond to fix their screw up and should be held as an example to what other companies especially triple A ones should be doing. 
Now the game play is pretty solid, most of the glitching has been fixed except a few outliers. The game could be better optimized my computer is much newer then this game so should not be running into any issues but the space stations can get a bit busy and lag dropping the fps significantly especially in multiplayer. The planets can get pretty repetitive and base building can be a chore as environment often comes back clipping into buildings. 
That negativity aside, it is fun to explore, customize your gear and now ships. There are many mechanics of the game that are fun to explore; like being a merchant, crashing markets, leaving the inhabitants of that galaxy with an economy reflecting Earth's current one. Or you can be a smuggler, getting contraband past space robot cops to make the suppressed entities happy and your wallet fat like a Santa that gets paid. Not only can you have a command ship and customize the inside to your liking, but you can purchase ships to make a fleet. This impressive fleet you build can be sent on missions; however, they may need the ever diligent commanders input on how to complete the mission or even need you to come to their rescue, or not, depending on what kind of captain you want to be.  This is a pretty fun game that is getting lots of love from the developers definitely worth trying out.

162492019.review:
So the infamous No Man's Sky and wow what a comeback!

It is the ultimate Survival Open Craft game out there. Allows incredible freedom, from terraforming, base building, quests/missions, cooking, many vehicles, decorations, interesting and random stuff you can find out in planets which i wont spoil for anyone.

The game does offer plenty of difficulty customization options including damage taken from hazards, economy, permadeath and even allows you to change them at anytime, even easing up the grind or make any purchase or building part completely free. Should be noted that  even at higher difficulty levels i wouldnt call the game a grind/difficult at all and it is quite relaxing.

It is undeniable that the game has a special feel to it in terms of scale, freedom and amazing vistas, but yes, eventually you'll see most variations of what this procedural generation masterpiece can do. Some of its mechanics could also have more depth and be more relevant to the gameplay loop itself as well as QOL improvements that were not provided since release like the UI, but still, after 100h, this game still does surprise me in terms of player choice. 

Be aware that many of all these updates, while free, are what keep bringing new people to the game which equals more sales while there are still some glaring issues/bugs that could have been solved instead of adding more features.

With this said, I still truly think that for people aiming for a sandbox environment with an imaginative mindset, that do like games like Teardown, Minecraft, Enshrouded or Valheim will probably love this game if you enjoy these with a space flair. 

Although it wont be for everyone, if you like to roleplay or just relax travelling through space, the cool RNG can bring wonderful and unexpected stuff to your table and it is up to you how to enjoy it in your own way.

Good Job Hello Games!

160605635.review:
No Man's Sky is an absolutely gem of a game. It will be probably be hard to say what hasn't already been said about this game. But I'll try to make it a short and direct review of the game.

For older gamers that grew up in the older PC era and you're familiar with the Elite games (Elite, Frontier: Elite II, Frontier: First Encounters), I think this is THE game you are looking for. This game expands on all of the greatest concepts that Elite introduced, plus adding absolutely tons of ideas to that.

On top of that, the game does a fantastic job NOT overwhelming the player with all of its many features all at once. It slowly introduces you to everything in the game with good pacing.

The developers have taken great care in honing all of the different systems in the game and making everything intuitive. For example, base building. Base building is easy to do, intuitive and works really well.  Or space combat, it has great control and is challenging and fun at the same time. It seems like they really took every single system in the game, and took care to focus on each one with thought and care.  

Play the game at our own pace, work on making some money, or follow story missions, or do side quests, or do government missions, or research new technology for your ship, or go hunt random pirates for cash, or build new vehicles to roam the planet and mine for resources, etc. You get the idea!

And this is maybe a small thing to point out, but having the travel methods so open really does give the player a sense of freedom within the game. For example...Standing at ground level at your base and looking up in the sky, and seeing a planet, then being able to hop in your ship and fly to the planet in real-time, then look back and see the planet you just came from, is a very cool sense of freedom. The same  goes for when you're entering a planet's atmoshere. The fact that you were flying the ship yourself as you enter, not just pressing a button and waiting for the planet to load up, is really huge part of what makes the game so much fun.

Talk about a feature rich game with endless amounts of things to do. This is a must-have game for anyone who likes large space combat/exploration/trading. If this type of game interests you, No Man's Sky does not disappoint!

No Man’s Sky is a remarkable journey through the boundless expanse of space, offering players an unparalleled adventure filled with discovery, wonder, and endless possibilities. From the moment you step foot on your first planet, you are immediately immersed in a breathtaking universe teeming with diverse landscapes, vibrant flora and fauna, and mysterious alien civilizations.

One of the most striking aspects of No Man’s Sky is its sheer scale and procedural generation technology, which ensures that no two experiences are ever the same. Each new planet you visit is a unique and awe-inspiring world waiting to be explored, with its own distinct climate, geography, and ecosystem. The sense of awe and excitement that comes from charting uncharted territory and stumbling upon hidden treasures is truly unparalleled.

The game's emphasis on exploration is further enhanced by its seamless integration of space travel and planetary exploration. Whether you're cruising through the cosmos in your customizable starship or embarking on foot to uncover the secrets of a distant world, the sense of freedom and adventure is palpable. The ability to seamlessly transition between different gameplay elements adds depth and immersion to the experience, ensuring that players are always engaged and entertained.

In addition to its expansive universe, No Man’s Sky also boasts a deep and engaging progression system that rewards players for their exploration and discovery. As you journey across the galaxy, you'll gather resources, upgrade your equipment, and learn new skills, allowing you to push further into the unknown and uncover even greater rewards. The sense of progression and growth is incredibly satisfying, providing players with a constant sense of accomplishment and purpose.

Furthermore, the recent updates and expansions to No Man’s Sky have only served to enhance the game's already impressive experience. From the addition of multiplayer functionality to the introduction of new features such as base building and vehicle customization, the developers have consistently listened to player feedback and delivered content that enriches the overall gameplay experience.

In conclusion, No Man’s Sky is a truly remarkable achievement in the world of gaming, offering players a vast and immersive universe to explore and discover. With its stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and endless possibilities, it's a game that will keep players coming back for more time and time again. Whether you're a seasoned space explorer or a newcomer to the genre, No Man’s Sky is an experience that should not be missed.

159841739.review:
No Man's Sky is a truly bizarre game. There are plenty of "space jobs" you can do, fulfilling different fantasies. You can be an exo-biologist, just going from planet to planet searching for and scanning lifeforms for money. You can be a miner, manually digging mineral deposits across a planet, or you can prospect for large mineral deposits, found a base and build mineral extractors. You can be a merchant, going system to system, buying locally produced goods and taking them where they are in demand. You can be a smuggler, buying contraband in Outlaw systems and selling them in lawful systems. You can be a pirate, raiding capital ships, or you can hunt pirates yourself. You can hunt Sentinels (i.e. mysterious synthetic space police), both on the ground and in space. You can scavenge derelict freighters, or you can command a fleet from your own capital ship. You can even become mayor of a town.
Each of these "space jobs" has different levels of fun, which of course is subjective, and of profitability. Yet they are all very shallow. They can be enjoyable, but you really need to immerse yourself in the world, because it is easy to rip through the paper thin facade and realize that you are playing a game and that everything is pointless. Yet, at least in my case, every time I rip through the veil of Maya, I can only put down the game for a few months, maybe a year, and then I get sucked right back in. That is why I have the playtime I do, and that is why I recommend it despite what I said until now.

Was able to play this game during the Omega release free play weekend. I had heard of this game for years, since release, but never really fought too hard to get it, as gamers always seemed a little torn on good/bad. I can say, without a doubt, that it is a pretty fun game at the current phase of update/release (again, known as Omega).

The starting sequence was fairly well laid out, with tutorials to get you moving in the right direction. Could more information be given during the tutorial? Yes! Is part of the game discovering things yourself and figuring out how to use them, survive, explore, etc? You bet! I realized about a day into the game that I wasn't doing the "visor" thing right to discover and catalog plants, animals, etc. Once I figured that out, I felt A) dumb for not seeing it earlier and B) awesome for finally figuring out how to find resources easier - targeting is dang genius!

The exploration, music, storage system, and options to advance your character seem a bit daunting at first, but then once you get a hang of it, things get a lot easier, but still remain fun and challenging. While I only got to sample the Omega Expedition that was currently underway, the ability to move your real character to an expedition and collect new stuff while it runs, returning to where you left off in the regular game, is pretty unique and fun. So many recipes, aircraft, building styles (check out Youtube for some of the most creative things people have built in this game), languages, and play styles available to you.

157274841.review:
Pro:
- The game is beautiful. The different Nebulae, the planets, the suns and overall visuals are superb. Really gives the exploring/immersion feeling a good boost. 
- Diversity is where the game truly shines. Sure, the pool from which the procedural generation picks is limited, but the combinations and overall spread of the different things you can find and catalog is superb. Collect ships, companions, freighters and invest hundreds of hours to fit and max them, fly them in adventures and see the galaxy.
- Good exploration sim.
- A lot of stuff to do with a scope in mind and completion goals. 
- Superb base designs. 
- Huge game, you will find places to call "home" and they will be beautiful.
- Music or should I say atmosphere is awesome. One of the best parts for me. 
- Great content with pirate dreads and alien like derelict explorations. Good immersion and feeling. 
- More ship slots! More freighters needed! I want to own a space armada please!

Cons: (this will hurt but every point here felt like a slap over the head when I played).
- The name of the game is Grind. Not because you have to slave away to have anything, but because you have to do the same thing tens/hundreds of times to reach the wanted result.
- The Click Hell! Want to skip over the same conversation 300th time? Click 20 times to fast force every sentence that slowly displays in the convo window. Alternatively, you will be taken out of vendor menu's so you have to reclick everything to get back, even thou you weren't finished! Click click click to skip everything, EXCEPT the entire conversation. Open again a lore journal by mistake? Start clicking to skip each sentence again. 30 clicks, done..Oh...another journal over there! Why the Hell are you being taken out of npc convo menus after each option you chose!?
- The difficulty is trivial. Even in the endgame content, there is no real danger. You get awesome ships armed to the teeth, a personal fleet, full rack of weapons, and you blast through derelict freighters with only an upgraded mining beam. 
- Horrible mechanic for scanning everlasting energy/resource nodes. In order to get the S-tier ones, you have to drive like a cretin in the same direction and scan. Hours upon hours of samey landscape where you just push a button to see if any RNG generated S-tier nodes are around you. WRONG! You have to spice up this torment by dismounting your vehicle hundreds of times because you cannot use the scanner while driving! It makes no sense! Why can't you use the scanner while flying/driving? 
- You can't change ship on station, you can't change the order of the ship you are being given after a scrap/sale. So get ready to teleport/fly around no one knows how many times because you are just not allowed on stations where you actually need to. 
- Map Cancer. The map is simply cancer. You want to set a waypoint? Hah! You see the road map only on locked view. Want to plan a trip? Get out in space, is the only place you can access the map! Besides this, the 3d map is so bad. Background colors change, systems overlap, you can't plot a course to a system you haven't visited, filter is simplistic, and you can't spin a 3d map. Good luck trying to pinpoint a system if you don't aim it perfectly with the center of your screen. Good luck trying to get anything to display unless you center it perfectly while flying.
- The Bugs. OMG, it's been 8 years already and still annoying bugs. 
  - terrain regrowing over your base.
  - falling through terrain and map
  - base registering screws the snap on base modules. All you can do is erase the entire base to make the modules snap and register the location on the same spot again, otherwise the game will not see your base as actually there, hence things won't snap anymore.
  - missions not registering progression. 
  - missions that ask impossible to achieve requirements (scan 12 flowers on a planet with no flowers)
  - things that display for me, do not display for my friends in multiplayer
  - resetting encounters with invisible enemies, etc
My gf quit on the game when all her inventory vanished during a Nexus mission losing rare items and tens of hours of progress getting them. 
- Multiplayer is NOT multiplayer. Sure, you can do missions with a friend, and battle sentinels or be a pirate (if you are lucky to see the same things on screen), but the multiplayer part (the reason why I bought the game with my gf) is not really there. Missions are trivial even on single player, so another person in your team just makes the ordeal go faster. Unless the game bugs and you get different requirements for the same mission :)) You can't use the same base unless the owner is online and ON SITE. You can't share the storage, you can't trade ships and "unboxed" modules (why???), You can't even build a shared base in the same spot. And while this is great for PVE and getting rid of thieves/griefers, it kills the coop game play and I feel scammed. 
- PVP is trivial and basically non existent. The NMS community is a hippie commune. The game itself is risk averse. There is no risk, no sweat, little skill involved and no punishment for failure on Normal. Hell, you only get tricked into pvp if you don't un-check a box. Even the predatory animals are slow! 
- I didn't care for the writing or the story. It's allover the place and the quests are 99% fetch quests. The mission UI is a mess also. Deselecting your missions when you enter ship, not giving clear checkpoints and making you resort to the messy galaxy map (accessible only while in space). But it's not why I played the game to begin with. The worst part is even if there is a large diversity of missions, their only goal is grind. Progressions IS GRIND. And they are RANDOM. You can't even grind what you need as a dedicated goal. Maybe this game session no missions with the rewards you need will spawn! Progression is therefore locked behind RNG, and that's a middle finger if you value your time. So get ready to check reddit for fastest ways to get through that grind faster! 
- the bases looks beautiful, and I've seen some incredible builds. Really jaw dropping material. The bad part, is that more than 50% of all the modules you can build in your base, are cosmetic only. There's no point going the extra mile. Some basic rooms/greenhouses/utilities and you are set for the rest of the game and fully outfitted. 
- The goal of many venues of game play mechanics is to give you money. Top tier farms for top tier minerals, rare plantations and expeditions providing with the rarest items, all have one utility - money. You can build entire bases by buying the materials off market, and it will barely make a dent in your wallet. And once you have everything you need and enough money, there's almost nothing to do in the game except grind for stuff you can't mine/build/buy. 
- cannot enjoy past expeditions and rewards given before I started :( 
- you can name everything, from systems to rocks...but they won't really show for you or others in space. The game forgets mapped planets and named systems. 

The game is extensive, but repetitive to braindead levels. The sandbox element is the saving grace. There are some incredible devs that managed to turn around a global scam and a global laughing stock of a game, and some designers/writers that should never touch a game again. The level of wasted potential in this game is staggering. It could have been one of the best games of the decade with all the things you could have done in it, instead, it's just a grindy "what could have been" with 0 replay value after a thorough game play. Respect for free dlc's, but the multiplayer aspect killed the main selling point for me. Buy it, but buy it on a sale.

If you're checking this game out with the expectation that it's a planet-hopping exploration game filled with interesting things to do (which is a fair expectation, considering all of the promotional material and the general premise of the game), you'll be sorely disappointed. The only difference between the planets are the types of elements on them for you to mine, and the colors. Once the giddy and awe wears off after exploring your first planet, there's not really much to be excited about.

None of the procedurally generated flora and fauna are interesting. There's very few unique structures or just things to do on planets. There's no reason to dig down and explore any more than just the surface. Gameplay loop is going to a planet, collecting the resources, selling them off at a space station, then jumping to another planet. Find a cool looking planet? You drop down, build a base, take screenshots, then leave. There is no change in the gameplay. The "quests" all just involve you going from one place to another or collecting specific resources.

I absolutely despise how this game is being hailed as having a massive comeback and being this amazing game when, in reality, it just got converted into a glorified base building simulator in space. If you're into that, then good for you. Maybe you'll like this game much more than I did. I played this solo, but it might be fun with friends? (though what game isn't)

162148327.review:
No Man's Sky is the gaming equivalent of a hyped 1st round draft pick who fumbles the bag in his first year, comes back next year and has a winning record, then the next year goes to the playoffs, then the next year wins the Super Bowl.  And when you think he's done?  He wins another ring.  And another, and so on.

This game is truly a labor of love, as it has been since its shaky launch, and if you don't think this game is worthy of being called a labor of love, then you have been living under a grease goblin's gaming chair.  This game has routinely been receiving committed fixes, updates, and new content since its inception in 2016.  That's almost a decade of work by this dedicated dev team.  For reference, in that span of time I have: graduated high school, graduated college, worked four different jobs, had several relationships (some long-term), and much more. And guess what? They're still updating this game.

I plan on playing this game for years to come, and I'm sure Hello Games will be hard at work on this game in those coming years.  Honestly, if they keep up at this rate, I'm excited to see the future state of the game.

I didn't buy this game at launch, but the launch fiasco for this game will go down in gaming history as a mere blemish in comparison to what the game has become.  It really is the greatest comeback in gaming, and it sets a great precedent to come for the gaming industry.  Sure, there's still plenty of room to grow, but no game is without flaw.

Figured I can at least leave a thumbs up on a review to show my support.  Incredible game and dev team.

I’ve had so much fun playing this game. It’s indeed a never-ending, limitless entertainment, especially for people like me who love open worlds with lots of stuff to find or build. 
I also find it really cool to see the regular free DLCs being added.

The only complaint I have is on how the naming planets/star systems work. Initially you’re very excited that you get to give a name to so much stuff and you believe all other players are going to find it, seeing your names on their galaxy maps. Turns out they get to see the unique names only if they click on specific star system for example. They won’t see any unique names right after opening the galaxy map, they will only see the default names. You’ll also see only the default names yourself unless you actually click on the star system you’ve named. This isn’t a huge deal as the game is so vast you quickly forget to care about this. Nevertheless in any multiplayer game which encourages to discover and name things I’d expect it to capture them and consequently update the view for all online players, including myself. So I don’t fully understand why I don’t get to see my own names on galaxy map…

I still recommend the game very much though. I’m very grateful I could play it so long before the Bethesda failure called Starfield which only confirms how well a game like NMS can be developed and win in every aspect against a product from a long existing company which takes ages to bring another boring game copied from their previous titles… well done!

159040579.review:
Will you have fun?  Most likely. 

No man's sky is now less of a game and more of a cultural phenomenon that captures what has made games fun over the past (almost) decade.  

It had a precarious launch with over-hype and over promise, and slowly year after year it's delivered more updates to increase it's sense of scale, immersion, and interactivity.  For me there was a core 50 to 100 hour gameplay loop where you can ramp up and build your space base, township, perfect ship, fleet, explore your heart out, max your character, or complete one of a couple main and side stories.  

Like any game, it doesn't have perfect immersion and after a while you'll start to see patterns in the core gameplay loop, each new and interesting planet feeling like a thematically similar copy of something you've seen before.  

In all honesty, don't start this game expecting it to be the last one you'll ever play.  It's great, just let it run it's course and figure out how far you want to go, whether solo or with friends.

It's been a roller coaster ride but NMS, after nearly 8 years, is probably the most consistently updated game in my entire Steam catalog. There's not much that you can ask for in a game that NMS doesn't have to some extent. You want a space shooter? Gotcha covered. How about an exploration game? There are so many systems that you'd never be able to explore them all (though they can get samey after a while). 3rd person shooter? It's not the best but it's passable. Love to grind up materials and watch the number go brrr? NMS is perfect for that. There's settlement sims, freighter and character customization, base building, and [b]so - much - more[/b]. On top of that we've gotten even better spacecraft customization.

If you like sandbox games, survival games, or even grinding games this should be at the top of your list. It's by no means perfect but most everything it does is at least a B-. I personally consider this as being one of my most worthwhile game investments - up there with Terraria and Minecraft. Folks, it just keeps getting better.

157205166.review:
This game has come a long way. It was rough around the edges when it came out, and it still is in a lot of ways. But they've poured time and attention into this and now there's way more to do. The sandbox is fun, the base building is fun, and the character progression feels great.

It's fundamentally shallow in a lot of ways. Every space station looks the same. 98% of NPCs all operate the same way (as a gimmick to play dialog mini games for knowledge or reputation). Combat is pretty subpar. The story makes absolutely no sense and many dialog choices will leave you wondering what you're agreeing to or the consequences of picking one thing over the other.

But under all this, there's a charming infinite universe to explore, cool ships to buy and upgrade, a great base building system, and lots of neat aliens to see. You start out scratching together ingredients for the most basic crafting but in no time you're jetting across superheated planets grabbing crystals to sell and carving out a cool home in the stars.

157192439.review:
Experiencing 'No Man's Sky' in VR is like discovering an entirely new game. While I've always enjoyed playing it on a monitor, the transition to VR, specifically using the Varjo Aero headset and Valve Index Controllers, has transformed my gameplay experience profoundly.

In this brief review, I want to focus not on the technical aspects, but on the unique emotional journey VR offers. This became particularly apparent in the shift in my playstyle, which I noticed was not a conscious decision.

Immersed in VR, my exploration of the game's universe has slowed down significantly. I find myself savoring every detail of each new planet I encounter. Currently, I am on a paradise world, which undoubtedly enhances this experience. The slower pace in VR contrasts sharply with my monitor gameplay, where I was more driven by technical progression and the thrill of advancement. In VR, my joy springs from the immersive visuals and the sensation of truly being present in these stunningly crafted environments, surrounded by exotic flora and fauna.

It's this shift from a focus on progression to a deeper appreciation of the virtual world around me that makes 'No Man's Sky' in VR a distinctly different, and profoundly more emotional, experience.

161438700.review:
I know what you're thinking. You want to get the game, but you're simply held back by the "wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle" over-used trope aren't you? I'll tell you right now you should forget about it. This applies perfectly to something like Elite Dangerous, where all planets are basically empty balls of dust, but that's clearly not the case with No Man's Sky.

So, I don't want to write an objective review of the game with objective pros and cons. I simply want to tell you what I like and don't like about the game.


Pros:

- Very beautiful and atmospheric
- A variety of planets with various compositions (minerals and flora to farm, depending what you need). Planets also have various dynamic effects such as fire storms, acidic rains, blizzards, and chemical storms, for which you require additional protection. You get additional minerals and rare substances like storm crystals, if you venture out during these storms.
- An amazing variety of ships of different classes, looks, and roles
- An astounding variety of gun systems and upgrades for them. Including illegal ones which you can purchase in Outlaw systems
- You can develop good terms with one faction, several, all, or go full pirate and f**k everything up
- Dynamic events. Pulse driving into a distant system can throw you into the middle of a pirate dreadnought attacking a civilian freighter. You can destroy the dreadnought (which will take time, is very dangerous, and requires a good ship), disable it, dock, and make it yours, or simply ignore it if it's too much for you
- You can build bases on whatever planet you choose and build them the way you like them. I've built mine on a planet with chemical storms, because I can farm storm crystals during the storms.
- You can travel through wormholes millions of lightyears into another corner of the universe to discover planets and systems that will carry your name from that point on
- The entire universe is lively and populated, which I didn't like at first, but I actually love now because there's always something to do
- You can find derelict freighters overwhelmed by some parasitic alien species living in some type of cocoons. You can enter them to collect high-value loot, but watch your steps. Moving too fast risks bursting the cocoons. 
- You can summon the Anomaly to join more difficult expeditions for greater loot, or take missions that other players can join in

Cons:

- The sentinels are a bit annoying. If they engage you while you're on-foot on a planet, you either hide, or fight them for 15 minutes, as they come in bigger and more difficult waves, or take off with your ship and they will send interceptors which you will also fight for quite a while.

- Wish there would be some more fighting going around, like total-war types systems with extremely high-value loot, where everybody fights over it. AI and players included.

Oh yea, I've heard it also has a main story. Can't comment on that, because I'm only 72 hours in and haven't started it yet.

Yes, I have no social life.

118188008.review:
No Man’s Sky is like a guy who owes you $1,000 from 6 years ago coming back with $10,000 to repay you after you thought the money was gone.

I really like this game. I’ve been playing it for years on and off, returning after every major update to see the state of things. No man’s Sky might be a fantastic game now, but you gotta always remember how it all begun. When the game first came out it could best be described to had been as wide as the ocean, but having the depth of a puddle. 

The game has improved so much from when it came out that it is easily one of my favorite space exploration games nowadays. One of the greatest redemption stories in video game history. It’s almost like they used the money they earned from sales  to actually improve the game. 

I love the idea of having this massive sandbox shared experience, where coincidentally anybody can stumble upon my little bases I scattered, mines, etc. I also love flying around the stars in my ship, discovering new planets, finding weird animals, plants, geography…

The sense of adventure and the thrill of finding some new world makes me have so much fun. If you like exploring and just taking your time  doing things, this game is a must, and I highly recommend it. 

The truth is no matter what you think of the game we should all be grateful of what we’ve gotten. If No Man’s Sky was made by EA, all these updates throughout the years would probably have been released as $60 new games each.

I’ll be honest, at this rate and with these devs I have a feeling No Man’s Sky has a better chance of of becoming what Star Citizen strives to be than Star Citizen.

Every now and then though, whenever I see a game trailer that I really enjoy, I like to remember the state of this game when it first came out and how awful it was. It keeps me in check and helps my expectations stay grounded.

10/10

90936710.review:
EDIT, 6 Sept 2021: No Man's Sky is no longer 'mixed'! Congratulations!


Original Review:
Don't let that "mixed" up there under review scores fool you: this game has changed SO much from its disastrous launch back in 2016. When this launched it was, as one commentator put it, "wide as an ocean, but shallow as a puddle." But Hello Games did something remarkable: instead of devolving into pay-to-win bullsh*t like we have seen time and time again, they sat back down, got to work, and have spent nearly five years releasing free update after free update, transforming the game in such a way it makes the launch build look like an early access beta.

Want to be an explorer and just find as many planets as possible? Go for it. Want to be a space pirate and just steal all the stuff you need instead? Go ahead. Want to stick to just a few planets and build a mega industrial complex that prints more money than 1920's Germany, then realise that you're way in over your head and need to build a money farm just to build your money farm? Have fun. And if any of this is too boring alone, toss down a portal and invite your friends to play. 

If you bought this back at launch and felt like it was boring or shallow, I say to you, give it another go. I did, and I can say wholeheartedly that I was not disappointed.
Bravo, Hello Games. Bravo.

66833423.review:
As everyone knows, No Man's Sky is a modern cautionary tale about pre-release game development. What not everyone knows, but people are slowly beginning to learn, is that it's also an exemplar of ongoing game development. Like many, I bought NMS at launch, and was underwhelmed by it. I wasn't outraged, as so many were, but it seemed like a great example of over-promising and under-delivering. I played enough to get bored with the mechanics, marveled a bit at the color and scope of the worlds while being frustrated with the mechanics, and blundered around without a very well-defined tutorial path. Then I went on to other things instead.

Four years later, all of the good things about NMS have been retained and improved, all of the bad things have been resolved, and features I never even hoped for have been added. The dev team has been responsive, engaged and imaginative. It would have been understandable for Hello Games to fold up, after an Icarus story so painfully acted out, but instead they doubled down on their commitments and have turned No Man's Sky into a genuinely wonderful gaming experience.

I honestly cannot say enough positive things about it. It is a shining example of how game development can work when driven by a team that wants to do the absolute best they can for their audience, delivering content-filled updates regularly without asking a penny more than the original cost of the game. I have looked for ways to give them more of my money, and have settled for evangelizing about it to all of my friends. Especially now - if you have free time, get NMS.

78374568.review:
One of my favorite games of all time. I have 'wasted' an embarrassing number of hours in this Sky. It is not a game for those who like a strong story or those who need a strong sense of direction. It truly shines as a kind of 'chose your own adventure' game. 

Do you want to just see how far you can explore and how many planets you can discover and name after your cat? You can do that. And while there is more than a little repetition in the plants and animals found on those planets, there is enough variety to keep it interesting. I have a rather extensive folder of the very different and exotic animals I have discovered in my travels including a cute teddy bear creature as tall as a building and others that you can ride just for the fun of it. 

Do you want to just try to find and upgrade the best ships in the galaxies to add to your collection on board your premium freighter that you finally found? You can do that. I have spent hours just looking for the best crashed ships that I can nab for free. It is like a galactic treasure hunt to find (and then upgrade) the most beautiful rides until you have a collection that Jay Leno would be envious of.  

Or maybe you dream of building the most luxurious, extensive, elaborate and just plain kick-ass base (or twenty of them) that anyone in this reality has ever seen? You can do that. In fact, you can build one that reaches into the sky, is underground, is under the oceans, on top of a mountain with a gorgeous view. And if you build more than one, you can travel to all of your vast real estate holdings in the blink of an eye thanks to the magic of portals. 

Or maybe ships and bases aren't your thing and you just want to become a tycoon with the most extensive collection of mining operations in the galaxies? You can do that too. Or maybe you just want to become a trader who becomes a billionaire by travelling between the different systems buying low and selling high. You can do that. Or maybe you want to become a billionaire but are also a bit of a treasure hunter? You can locate and sell historic artifacts, old bones, ancient tech. 

There is just so much to do in this big, beautiful game that you can just follow your whim and do what you want. Make your own goals and then make them happen. Or don't set any goals and just meander. Do what you want and just have fun in the infinite universe!

60244380.review:
Launch controversy aside, what this game should have been called for the longest time is 'Early Access'. Around the time of the Beyond update is when I'd say would have been the true 'launch'. 

I didn't get this when it first came out, but even when I did it was a fragmented mess of a game. Now, finally, with the Beyond and Synthesis updates there's a solid game here that's almost (but not quite) like what Sean Murray promised way back at the beginning.

Performance on PC has dramatically improved with the switch over to the Vulkan API, and it finally supports Ultrawide and various other PC-specific options. The game itself provides a significant amount of variety, offering a combination of Elite-lite and 'Minecraft in Space' mechanics. There's plenty to see and do, and the exploration aspect is enjoyable - if a little bland. The planetary biomes and overall game could still do with further diversity, but there's plenty here to get to your teeth into.

Hello Games show no sign of slowing down their support for the game either, having just recently released a bizarre in-game music synthesizer of all things, and going by the evidence of their progress to date I can only see the game improving further as time moves on.

EDIT - 24/09/2020 "Origins" Patch: well, you can ignore the previous comments about diversity being a bit on the low side. They already added things like living ships, derelicts, space creatures and robots since I made this review, and with the Origins patch the variety of experience on offer is on such a scale now that I don't think I'm going to be lacking for things to do for some time. Also, impressively, the game runs even better than it did when I originally posted this - and the rejigged UI looks fantastic on Ultrawide. 

Brilliant work by the team at Hello Games. I can't think of any game I've played (and I've been indulging since the late 80's) where I've ever gone from "I can't stand this" to "this is one of my favourite games". It's taken a while to get here, but No Man's Sky is definitely one of the greats.

125385497.review:
Honestly I can't recommend this game enough. The developers being absolute chads is reason enough for me. let me give you the timeline of updates so you can make your own opinion though.

The Foundation Update - November 2016
Now you can build a base on planets and farm resources from them as well as a plethera of other things you can use to make a base that really fits your needs and looks good while you're at it. 

The Pathfinder Update - March 2017
Now you can build underground garages in those bases and drive a whole fleet of vehicles around the planet for easy access to places starships can't get to. And it also looks bad-ass.

The Atlas Rises Update - August 2017
Now instead of aimlessly wandering around the galaxy you can follow a storyline that will simultaneously show you the intricacies of the game, and peak your curiosity. 8/10 story overall for me.

No Mans Sky Next Update - July 2018
Possibly the biggest update the game ever received. This update turned the lonesome singleplayer experience into a full co-op. The greatest thing? It's all optional. When in-game, simply go to settings and find the Network section, there you can toggle all multiplayer actions, and you can even disable the multiplayer entirely. Just watch out for endgame players suddenly giving you overpowered items, or trolls giving you trash items for fun. There isn't a way to toggle other players "gifting" you things yet, but we hope this will be a feature soon.

The Abyss Update - October 2018
One of my personal favorites. This update adds entire oceans to the game, and even some planets that are one big ocean. This also added a whole plethera of marine plants and animals, and underwater ruins sometimes filled with, ahem, ABYSSAL HORRORS. The game calls them that, and I fully agree. 

The Visions Update - November 2018
This update added a huge variety to the planets of the galaxy. It added new trees, plants and flowers, new minerals, and rock formations, new animals to roam those new lands, and rainbows and exotic trophies to hunt down inside these new environments. It also added ancient bones you could dig up and buried scrap you could salvage. As well as new community missions that helped people earn rewards as a group.

No Mans Sky Beyond - August 2019
This update worked to expand the variety in the settlements and space stations, as well as improving the Nexus Hub (The social hub for players to interact). This update also added VR support to the game. While it does take a beefy pc to run VR well, and there is still no left-handed support, the experience of a space battle in VR, exploring a planet in VR, and talking with other people in VR is quite the unique experience.

The Synthesis Update - November 2019
This was another quality of life update, improving upon many different aspects of the game. To list the major things, an improved Star Map on your spaceship, ways to upgrade your starship, ways to scrap uneeded starships, improvements to the Terrain Manipulator (The tool used for digging and moving the ground), and a way to save outfits for character customization. As well as many other smaller improvements,

The Living Ship Update - February 2020
As the name might suggest, this update added a freaking M E A T S H I P. You get it by doing a questline in which you hatch a mysterious egg. And yeah, it's a little gross to look around the inside of the cockpit. This update also added many new space encounters (One of my favorite parts of the game). Now you can find weird space creatures, destroyed starships, and even trader ships or another pilot who needs some help. 

The Exo Mech Update - April 2020
A pretty small update really. It added a new vehicle to walk around planets in: the Exo Mech. The Exo Mech is pretty cool and very useful for a lot of different things. It also improved the system of other Exocraft vehicles, and added a Orbital Exocraft Materializer, which allows you to take your Exocraft with you on your giant spaceship.

The Crossplay Update - June 2020
Another smaller update. This update added crossplay, a new in-game text chat, and a friending system to easily meet with your friends. Besides some other small tweaks nothing else was added.

(You can kinda tell that 2020 hit the Devs hard because of how much smaller the updates got. Don't worry though, they didn't give up on the game.)

The DESOLATION Update - July 2020
Another one of my personal favorites. Did you ever wonder if No Mans Sky could be a horror game? Well, now you can find giant derelict freighters that are filled with gross flesh bugs that will shoot E Y E L A S E R S. Oh, and your life support and hazard protection are dropping fast so you have to collect little packets along the way and huddle next to heaters to not freeze to death. This update also added numerous lighting improvements and added ways to customize and upgrade your Freighter.

The No Mans Sky Origins Update - September 2020
No, I don't know why some updates have NMS in the name and some don't, ask the devs. Anyways, this update overhauled planets again, adding new biomes, hazards, buildings settlements, and some pretty major bug fixes  too. Just a nice little variety update.

The Halloween 2020 Update - December 2023... No, obviously it's October 2020. (Idiot)
This update is another creepy one. It improved the derelict Freighters you could find, and it added Tainted Metal. Tainted Metal is a rare resource found during derelict Freighter excursions, you can use Tainted Metal to buy all sorts of spooky cosmetics and decorations for your base. You can even get your hands on a M E A T H E L M E T. nice.

The Next Generation Update - Also October 2020
This update focused on improving the game for console players. (Masterace Forever). It gave the game much better performance on consoles and also increased the max group size of multiplayer to 32. Don't expect it to load very fast though.

The Companions Update - February 2021
This update is yet another of my personal favorites. This update added the ability to tame and train creatures. You could tame a wild animal of your liking, and generation after generation manipulate the eggs to improve and alter your creatures. Now people can walk around with their 50th Generation Mr. Bubbles the space tiger and ride them at 100000000 mph. A very wholesome little update :)

The Expeditions Update - March 2021
This was a very unique update. Not only did it include many important improvements and tweaks, this update also gave rise to the Expeditions. Expeditions are limited time voyages a player can complete for permanent cosmetic rewards. The First expeditions final reward, for example, was the spaceship Golden Vector. An S-tier ship made of solid gold, and a pretty sleek design. Once you were awarded a cosmetic or even useful reward, you could visit a Quicksilver Merchant in the Nexus Hub to collect the reward on all other saves on your account. new and old. Many updates afterward featured unique Expeditions to showcase the new content.

The Prisms Update - June 2021
This update is pretty simple. They improved the visuals of the game. Space is pretty.

The Frontiers Update - September 2021
This is a pretty big update. they added new settlements that you could manage and build up. Not like your puny little base, these are big towns with citizens and everything. Now you can settle disputes between your colonists, approve and oversee construction of new buildings, and improve the infrastructure of your colony so you can start making credits by the millions.
The update also came with many improvements to your own base building capabilities, and some quality of life changes, including more save slots.
 
Welp, I've hit the cap for reviews. Here's a link to the source I used: https://www.thegamer.com/no-mans-sky-every-update-expansion-dlc-content/

And thanks to the suggestion of someone much smarter than me I will continue the review in the comments! Thanks to WouldYouKindly for suggesting it

One of the best comeback stories in modern videogames. Strongly recommend for any would-be scifi adventurer into spaceships, alien worlds and space exploration, and base building or resource exploiting. I absolutely HATED this game at release after it absolutely botched the landing in apocalyptic fashion, turning all of the hype around it into one of the most stunningly underwhelming and disappointing slogs I'd ever played. 68748064.review:
No Man's Sky has come a long way since its initial release. There's a lot to enjoy now, but there are some things I feel I need to mention to gamers like me who are reconsidering this title in 2020.

First, the good news. There is a fair amount of gameplay variety these days: running missions, space combat, building a base, and upgrading your equipment. And yes, you can now do all these things with your friends -- the game supports co-op sessions with up to 4 people.

However, the game is still, at its core, a single-player experience focused on exploring new planets and scanning alien life forms. And unfortunately, most of the other features feel like an afterthought by comparison. Some examples:

- Your progress is saved locally. If the game crashes (and it will), you will lose your progress. This is very confusing in a game that portrays itself as a persistent open world adventure.

- Your base is saved locally, and uploaded to the server periodically. If the game crashes, there is potential for major conflicts, such as two copies of your base being stacked on top of one another, which leads to permission issues and the inability to remove the old copy. Extremely frustrating. The problems compound when you try to build a base with a friend. In our squad, this was easily the most disappointing part of the game.

- Because of the local saving, it is very easy to edit your save file to load unlimited supplies and equipment. The server does NOT verify your inventory.

- There is no resource scarcity. In a game about finding and collecting resources, this feels very odd. Once you get past a certain threshold of "units" (the in-game currency), you can easily purchase huge quantities of items on the market, or buy a new ship to shoot NPCs with impunity. The challenge factor goes way down at that point, and consequently so does the fun.

- For all the development effort that has gone into the game of late, there seems to have been a severe lack of QA. The game crashes A LOT. Bugs abound; some are hilarious, some are infuriating.

That being said, this can still be a fun game to put 30-40 hours into with your friends. Save often. Upload your base any time you make even the smallest change. Warp throughout the galaxy, check out new planets, and marvel at the visually-impressive worlds and curious alien life forms you'll encounter.

Base building is not as good as Rust. Space combat is not as good as Elite Dangerous. The market is not player-driven as it is in EVE. The gunplay is subpar by any measure.

But No Man's Sky does all these things _pretty decently_, and the result is a fun romp around the galaxy.

[b]6/10[/b]
